page.addressleaf:
fol.263v
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham Knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
28 Martij
1590
M
r
Bodely to M
r
Secretary Walsingham
Newe Custome imposed by
e states, uppon
e English clothes.
The
Councell of state
complayne of want of answer in writing from
e
LLs of
e Councell
here to their peticions./
28 Ma
r
90
page.lettertext:
fol.262r
It may please yo
r
H. to be advertised,
at
I receaved of late a letter from my LL. of
the Councel, w
t
charge to deale w
t
e
General
States
, about
e relaxation of a certaine
newe custome, imposed by
e
states of Hol-
land
upon Englishe clothes. Also to the
same effect
e Company of marchants ad-
venturers have written unto me from
Middle-
bourgh
. Howbeit it is but in general termes,
w
t
out any specification what custome it is,
wherew
t
they finde themeselves aggrieved: nether
can I learne it otherwise, by any that are heere.
Wherupon I am forced to attend a further
information from
e marchants: and having
receaved it, I will doe my uttermost dili-
gence, in folowing their cause. This
day
e Councel of State hath dispatched a letter
to my LL. of her
Ma
ties
Councel, in answear
to
at w
ch
M
r
Wilkes
delivered by worde of
mouth to
M
r
Ortel
, concerning their late pe-
titions: wherein they complaine
at it pleased
not my LL. in divers maters of speciall mo-
ment to yeld an answear unto them in wai-
ting. They have also written to M
r
Ortel,
to whome they specifie those pointes of their
former letter, whiche they would have to be
solicited, till their LL. answear be ob-
tened. For mine owne part I have
signified unto them, that they can hardly
complaine in any suche cause for want of an
answear. For her Ma
tie
hath of late, at
sundrie times, both by her owne letters and
otherwise required an answear from the
fol.262v
Generall states to causes of as great or greater
importance, wherto they have made no answear,
nether by worde nor by writing. Moreover
there was litle contened in their late letter,
wherunto they had not already, both from me
and otherwise, receaved satisfaction, as I par-
ticularly declared. But partly by them-
selves and partly otherwise I might perceave,
that they had bin charged expressly by
e
General states, to require
at answear in wri-
ting, w
ch
M
r
Wilkes imparted by worde of
mouth. I can not conjecture whereunto
this curiositie of
e states doth tend, unles it
be to have somwhat, to alleage unto
e Provinces
thereby to serve their owne turnes, as if her Ma
tie
had no care of observing
e Contract: whiche
may happely appeere, if it may please yo
r
H.
uppon M
r
Ortels solicitation, to require his
demaundes to be sett downe in writing.
And
so I take my humble leave. From the
Hage
. 28 Ma
r
A
o
90.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
